CatDescriptText: Mr. George Knohl, telephone answering service manager, and Mr. Joseph (Joe) Williams, clerk, North Side, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 22, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you believe Negroes in Pittsburgh are as militant about Civil Rights like others of their race display in other Metropolitan areas in the USA? Why?" Mr. Knohl's answer reads: "Outspoken as Negroes in the South are, and like they should be. Also they are not as outspoken as Negroes are in Chicago.  Perhaps it's because the Negro here doesn't have the backing like he does in the South.  Down there, Negroes are in a group, and they..."  Mr. Williams' answer reads: "No, I don't think so, and one reason is because we don't have proper leadership.  I refer to what people think of as 'leadership.'  This group holds political jobs, therefore the 'leaders' are tied.  We must have independent leadership.  I personally think people are not interested in sacrificing and they are not for the race as a whole."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of George Knohl wearing light colored shirt and diagonally striped necktie, standing on sidewalk, Downtown; Portrait of Joseph "Joe" Williams wearing eyeglasses, striped short sleeve shirt, and plaid necktie with clip, standing on sidewalk, Downtown
